bestBHT.bht: In Mark 5:2, we encounter a man who had an unclean spirit that had possessed him for a long time. While Matthew mentions that there were two individuals with demonic possession, Mark focuses on this specific case, perhaps because this man was the fiercest and had a legion of demons within him. The demon-possessed man immediately recognized Jesus and greeted Him, showing the immediate power and authority that Jesus had over the spiritual realm. Mark provides additional details about this miracle that Matthew and Luke do not include, emphasizing the unique aspects of this encounter.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Though there be no discrepancy between these two statements—more than between two witnesses, one of whom testifies to something done by one person, while the other affirms that there were two—it is difficult to see how the principal details here given could apply to more than one case.
there met him a man with an unclean spirit 'which had devils [demons] long time'
In Matthew (Luke 8:27- :), 'there met him two men possessed with devils.'
Philip Schaff: A man. Matthew tells of ‘two,’ being more particular in this respect. Luke speaks of but one.
With, lit., ‘in ‘ an unclean spirit. Mark usually prefers this form of describing demoniacal possession.
Archibald T. Robertson: Out of the boat (εκ του πλοιου). Straightway (ευθυς) Mark says, using the genitive absolute (εξελθοντος αυτου) and then repeating αυτω associative instrumental after απηντησεν.
The demoniac greeted Jesus at once.
Mark has many touches about this miracle not retained in Matthew and Luke.
John Gill: The Jews have a notion, that a man by dwelling among the tombs, becomes possessed with an unclean spirit.
This case is the same with that, which is mentioned in Matthew 8:28.
Mark may only take notice of this one, because he was the fiercest of the two, and had the most devils in him, having a legion of them.
John Wesley: There met him a man with an unclean spirit — St. Matthew mentions two."
Probably this, so particularly spoken of here, was the most remarkably fierce and ungovernable.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Mark 5:2, we encounter a man who had an unclean spirit that had possessed him for a long time. While Matthew mentions that there were two individuals with demonic possession, Mark focuses on this specific case, perhaps because this man was the fiercest and had a legion of demons within him. The demon-possessed man immediately recognized Jesus and greeted Him, showing the immediate power and authority that Jesus had over the spiritual realm. Mark provides additional details about this miracle that Matthew and Luke do not include, emphasizing the unique aspects of this encounter.

In this account, Mark recounts the encounter of a man who had long been tormented by an unclean spirit. Though Matthew mentions two individuals, Mark focuses on this specific case, highlighting the intensity of this man's possession with a legion of demons within him. Mark's narration vividly portrays the immediacy with which Jesus is recognized and greeted by this demoniac, underscoring the authority and power that Jesus had over the spiritual realm. Mark provides unique details about this particular miracle, offering a deeper understanding of the significance of this encounter.

In this passage, Mark describes the encounter of a man who was possessed by an unclean spirit for a long time. While Matthew mentions two individuals with demonic possession, Mark focuses on the details of this particular case, perhaps because the man was the fiercest and had a legion of demons within him. Mark's account highlights the immediate recognition and greeting of Jesus by the demon-possessed man, showcasing Jesus' authority over the spiritual realm. Mark's narration provides additional insights into this significant miracle not found in the other Gospel accounts.

In this account, a man with a long-standing possession by an unclean spirit encounters Jesus. While Matthew mentions two people with demonic possession, Mark focuses on the details of this particular case, possibly due to the man's fierce nature and the multitude of demons within him. Mark portrays the instant recognition and greeting of Jesus by the demoniac, demonstrating Jesus' authority over the spiritual realm. Mark's narrative offers unique insights into this remarkable miracle that are not present in other Gospel records.

In this encounter, Mark vividly describes a man who had long been afflicted by an unclean spirit. While Matthew mentions two individuals, Mark's focus is on the particular details of this case, as this man was the fiercest and had a legion of demons within him. Mark emphasizes the immediate recognition and greeting of Jesus by the demon-possessed man, showcasing Jesus' authority over the spiritual realm. Mark's account provides unique insights into this remarkable miracle, expanding our understanding of this extraordinary event.
